contextId.information: The word "himself" is a reflexive pronoun that refers back to Satan, and it is also a metonym for his evil spirits. AT: "If Satan and his evil spirits were fighting one another" (UDB) or "If Satan and his evil spirits have risen up against each other and are divided" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If Satan has risen up against himself and is divided

contextId.information: Here "himself" emphasizes that Jesus was alone in the stern. AT: "Jesus himself was alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
The word "herself" is a reflexive pronoun used to emphasize that it was significant that it was Herodias' own daughter who danced at the dinner. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
This word "himself" refers to David and is used to place emphasis on him and what he said. AT: "It was David who" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
